abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Marsyangdi
            Hydroelectric Power Project for Nepal was satisfactory. The
            project successfully achieved its physical objectives, its
            impact on institutional development was marginally
            successful, and sustainability is likely. However, both the
            Bank and Borrower performed less than satisfactorily
            overall. Several lessons can be learned from this project.
            First, the successful operation of the Marsyangdi plant
            suggests that the detailed planning, execution, and
            monitoring of operation and maintenance carried out in this
            plant should be applied in other facilities in NEA's
            system. Second, projects with large, lumpy physical
            components should be submitted to Board consideration only
            after bidding for the main components has taken place.
            Third, the project illustrates the fact that borrowers and
            beneficiaries tend to own physical project components of IDA
            projects more clearly than institutional ones. Fourth, a new
            strategy in line with the current power sector policy
            guidelines of the Bank Group needs to be developed. Fifth,
            IDA created a precedent that when HMG and NEA were not in
            compliance with their commitments, these covenants were
            shifted to the next projects. Lastly, IDA should ensure that
            the necessity to undertake rehabilitation and restoration of
            livelihood of project affected families be accepted as a
            principle by HMG.
